instruction: How did the study validate the possibility of glioma diagnosis using fresh tissue and provide instant feedback for neurosurgeons in guiding maximal safe resection?
Output:
The study validated the possibility of glioma diagnosis using fresh tissue by using a portable VRR-LRRTM Raman analyzer to analyze the biochemical differences between normal and different grades of glioma tissues in real-time. The accuracy in identifying glioma from normal tissue using this method was over 80%, compared with histopathology as the gold standard. This means that the Raman analyzer was able to successfully distinguish between normal and glioma tissues. 

By providing instant feedback to neurosurgeons, the Raman analyzer can guide maximal safe resection of glioma. The real-time analysis of glioma tissue allows surgeons to identify the boundaries of the tumor during surgery, helping them to remove as much of the tumor as possible while preserving adjacent healthy tissue. This feedback is crucial in ensuring that the surgical procedure is effective and safe.

instruction: How does the use of the portable VRR-LRRTM Raman analyzer compare to traditional methods in terms of accuracy and real-time diagnosis of glioma during surgery?
Output:
The use of the portable VRR-LRRTM Raman analyzer in diagnosing glioma during surgery has shown promising results in terms of accuracy and real-time diagnosis compared to traditional methods. According to the study mentioned in the text, the accuracy of identifying glioma from normal tissue using the VRR-LRRTM Raman analyzer was over 80%, which is a significant improvement compared to relying solely on histopathology reports as the gold standard.

Traditional methods of glioma diagnosis often involve postoperative analysis of tissue samples, which can be time-consuming and may not provide real-time feedback to guide surgeons during the surgery. In contrast, the VRR-LRRTM Raman analyzer allows for instant feedback by analyzing the biochemical composition of fresh glioma tissue in real-time.

The study also mentions the use of a machine learning method, specifically the principal component analysis-support vector machine (PCA-SVM), to distinguish glioma tissues from normal tissues and different grades of glioma.
